div.ab:
ὑπατείαςὑπατίας τοῦ δεσπότου ἡμῶν Ὁνορίου
τοῦ αἰωνίου ΑὐγούστουἈγούστου τὸ ια καὶ Φλαουίου
Κωνσταντίου, λαμπρΚωσταντίου τοῦ λαµπροτάτου πατρικίου month day
ὁµολογεῖ Αὐρήλιος Ἰσι
ἐλαιουργόςαιλεουργω

item.p: Fl. Constantius was patricius from 415 until he was ephemerally proclaimed Augustus in 421 (he died in the same year); see PLRE II 323. The title, however, is only seldom recorded in dating formulas, the only other certain instances being Pap.Colon. XII.3 (in Aramaic transcription) and P.Oxy. VIII 1134.2 (421); see CSBE2 194 for other doubtful instances from 421. It is theoretically not impossible that π[ represents the month Π[αχων or Π[αυνι, but this is rendered very unlikely by the fact that the latest post-consular dating by the previous year’s consuls is from 21 Pauni = 15 June (see 1–3 n.); it is indeed very rare for the names of new consuls to be disseminated as early as June in fifth-century Egypt (see CSBE2 93). There probably would not be sufficient space for the restoration of the iteration numeral τὸ β after π[ατρικίου. The number is present only in P.Oxy. 4904.2. The two papyri dated by the post-consulate of Honorius and Constantius (see 1–3 n.) do not specify that this is Constantius’ second time as consul (this is not completely certain for CPR X 111.3; see the editor’s note), nor does Pap.Colon. XII according to its editors (pp. 26–7).

The last trace is compatible with sigma. Reading a dative form (ἐλαιουργῷ) would suggest a reference to the profession of the second party, but the preceding space is too short to include the names and patronymics of both parties.
